question: Choose the true statement.
answer1: If the kernel of a linear transformation $T:\mathbb{R}^3\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^3$ is $\left\{(0,0,0)\right\}$, then $T$ is an isomorphism.
answer2: If the kernel of a linear transformation $T:\mathbb{R}^3\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^4$ is $\left\{(0,0,0)\right\}$, then $T$ is an isomorphism.
answer3: If the kernel of a linear transformation $T:\mathbb{R}^2\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^3$ is $\left\{(0,0)\right\}$, then $T$ is an isomorphism.
answer4: If the kernel of a linear transformation $T:\mathbb{R}^3\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^3$ is $\left\{(0,0,x):x\in\mathbb{R}\right\}$, then $T$ is an isomorphism.

question:
The Cost-Less Corp. supplies its four retail outlets from its three plants. The shipping cost per unit from each plant $(i)$ to each retail outlet $j$ is given below.
	
\[
\begin{array}{lc|cccc}
&   & & \text{Retail} &\text{ outlet} \\
& & \text{K} & \text{L} & \text{M} & \text{N}\\
\hline
& \text{A} & 2 & 4 & 5 & 1 \\
\text{Plant} & \text{B} & 3 & 4 & 5 & 7 \\
& \text{C} & 4 & 5 & 7 & 4 \\
\end{array}
\]	
	
Plants $A$, $B$ and $C$ make $80$, $110$ and $130$ units per month, respectively. Retail outlets $K$, $L$, $M$, and $N$ need to receive $80$, $30$, $90$ and $120$ units per month, respectively. Use the transportation simplex method to determine the best plan for how many units to send from each plant to the respective retail outlets each month, minimizing the total shipping cost. Use the minimum cost rule to obtain an initial basic feasible solution. 
	
Choose the right answer:

Consider the vectors of $\mathbb{R}^3$, $v_1=(2, 0, 1)$, $v_2=(1, -1, 3)$, $v_3=(1, 1, -2)$ and $v_4=(3, 1, 0)$. Choose the right answer:
answer1: The set $\{v_1, v_2, v_3\}$ is linearly dependent but $\{v_1, v_2, v_4\}$ is linearly independent.
answer2: $v_4$ is a linear combination of $v_1$ and $v_3$
answer3: The space generated by $\{v_1, v_2, v_3\}$ is $\mathbb{R}^3$
answer4: $v_3$ is a linear combination of $v_2$ and $v_4$

The Omega Manufacturing Company has discontinued the production of a certain unprofitable product line. This act created considerable excess production capacity. Management is considering devoting this excess capacity to one or more of three products; call them products 1, 2, and 3. The available capacity on the machines that might limit output is summarized in the following table:
	
	\[\begin{array}{|c|c|}
			\hline
			\text{Machine Type} & \text{Available Time (machine hours per week)} \\
			\hline
			\text{Milling machine} & 500 \\
			\text{Lathe} & 350 \\
			\text{Grinder} & 150 \\
			\hline
			\end{array}\]
	
The number of machine hours required for each unit for a given product is the following:
	
		\[\begin{array}{|l|c|c|c|}
			\hline
			\text{Machine Type} & \text{Product 1} & \text{Product 2} & \text{Product 3} \\
			\hline
			\text{Milling machine} & 9 & 3 & 5 \\
			\text{Lathe} & 5 & 4 & 0 \\
		\text{Grinder} & 3 & 0 & 2 \\
			\hline
		\end{array}\]
	
	The sales department indicates that the sales potential for products 1 and 2 exceeds the maximum production rate and the sales potential for product 3 is 20 units per week. The unit profit would be 50?, 20?, and 25? for products 1, 2, and 3, respectively. The objective is to determine how much of each product the company should produce to maximize the profit. Formulate a linear programming model for this problem, considering that $x_{i}$ is the number of units of product $i~(i = 1~to~3)$ produced.

answer1: There are $1$ local maximum and $1$ saddle point.
answer2: There are $1$ local minimum and $1$ saddle point.
answer3: There are $1$ local maximum and $1$ local minimum.

question: Consider in the three-dimensional cartesian system the plane of equation $\pi: 2x-3y+z-1=0$. Choose the right answer:
answer1: The plane $\pi$ contains the point $P=(-1, -1, 0)$ and is normal to the vector $n=(-4, 6, -2)$.
answer2: The plane $\pi$ contains the point $P=(1, 1, 0)$ and is parallel to the vector $n=(2, 3, 1)$.
answer3: The plane $\pi$ contains the point $P=(1, 1, 1)$ and is normal to the vector $n=(2, -3, 1)$.
answer4: The plane $\pi$ contains the point $P=(1, -1, 0)$ and is parallel to the vector $n=(2, -3, 1)$.

answer2: $M(\frac{2}{3},\frac{1}{3},1)$ is the minimizer and $N(\frac{2}{3},\frac{1}{3},1)$ is the maximizer.

Medical researchers analyze how different dosages of a drug affect the duration of relief from allergic symptoms. They want to develop a statistical model to predict the time of relief (in days) based on the dosage of a new drug. Identify the predictor variable and the response variable.
answer1: The predictor variable is a dosage of a new drug; the response variable is the time of relief.
answer2: The predictor variable is the time of relief; the response variable is the dosage of the new drug.
answer3: The predictor variable is the mean of time of relief; the response variable is the mean of dosage of the new drug.
answer4: The predictor variable is the mean of dosage of a new drug; the response variable is the mean of time of relief.

Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
-x & + & y & + & z & = & 1 \\
 & & y & + & 3z & = & 2 \\
x &  &  & + & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(1,\,2,\,0\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has an infinite number of solutions, which are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,\frac{y}{2}\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: The system has $\left(0,\,-2,\,-1\right)$ as its unique solution.

Find the solutions $\left(\text{in } \mathbb{C}^2\right)$ of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
(1+i)z& + & (1-i)w & = & i \\
(1-i)z& + & (1+i)w & = & 1-i
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The unique solution of the linear system is $\bigg(\frac{3+i}{4},-\frac{1+i}{4}\bigg)$.
answer2: The solutions of the linear system are of the form $\bigg(\frac{1+i}{4},\frac{-1+i}{4}+z\bigg)$, for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.
answer3: The linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has the vector $(i,-i)$ has its unique solution.

question: Using the principal argument, the polar form of $z=1-\sqrt{3}i$ is

Find the solution of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
&x &+ &y &+ &z &= &0 \\ 
&-x &- &y &+ &2z &= &0 \\ 
&3x &- &y &- &5z &= &0
\end{cases}$$
answer3:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter:
$$(3+z,2-2z,z),\, \forall z\in \mathbb{R}$$.
answer4:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameter:
$$(3+z+y,y,z),\, \forall y,z\in \mathbb{R}$$.

Consider the differentiable function $f:\mathbb{R}^{3}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $f(x,y,z)=x^{2}yz-\cos \left( xyz\right) +xe^{yz}.$ Find $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x},\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y},\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}.$
answer1:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=2xyz+yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z+xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y+xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer2:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=2xyz-yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z-xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xyze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y-xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer3:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=xyz+yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z+xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xe^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y+xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer4:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=xyz-yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z-xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y-xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xyze^{yz}$

question:

$$\left\{\begin{array}{cccccccc}

x & + & 2y & + & z & = & c
\end{array}\right.$$
answer1: There is no $(a,b,c)\in\mathbb{R}^{3}$ for which the linear system has no solutions.

answer1: Dilation (isotropic scaling) of centre $(0,0)$ and scale factor $2$.

question: Find the integral curve which satisfies the equation $tx'-x=-2t^2x^2$ with initial condition $x(1)=1$.
answer1: The integral curve that satisfies the initial condition is the curve $x(2t^3+1)-3t=0$.
answer2: The integral curve that satisfies the initial condition is the curve $x(2t^3+3)-t=0$.
answer3: The integral curve that satisfies the initial condition is the curve $\frac{x}{2t^3+1}-3t=0$.
answer4: The integral curve that satisfies the initial condition is the curve $x=\frac{2t^3+1}{3t}$.

answer1: $x=0$ is a maximizer, and $x=4$ is a minimizer.
answer2: $x=1$ is a maximizer, and $x=4$ is a minimizer.
answer3: $x=0$ is a maximizer, and $x=2$ is a minimizer.

question: Consider the linear operator $F:\mathbb{R}^2 \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^2$ such that $F(x,y)=(x+2y,2x+3y)$. Choose the right answer:
answer1: $F^{-1}$ is a symmetric operator defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(-3x+2y, 2x-y)$
answer3: $F^{-1}$ is defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(3x-2y, -2x+y)$ and is not a symmetric operator
answer4: $F^{-1}$ is a symmetric operator defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(3x-2y, 2x-y)$

How many solutions does the following linear system have?
$$\begin{cases}
x & - & y & + & z & - & 2t & = & 0 \\
-x & - & 5y & + & z & - & 8t & = & 0 \\
2x & + & y & + & z & + & t & = & 0 \\

\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameters.
answer2: The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter.
answer4: The system has a unique solution.

A consulting firm will carry out two types of projects ($A$ and $B$). The development cost per project $A$ and $B$ is, respectively, $1$ and $2$ monetary units. The requirements in terms of analysts, programmers and terminals for each type of project, are indicated in the following table:

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Project} & \text{N. of programmers}  & \text{N. of analysts}  & \text{N. of terminals} \\
\hline
\text{A} & 2 & 2 & 3 \\
\text{B} & 3 & 6 & 1 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]

The company wants to minimize the cost of developing projects in the next period. In the development of these projects, at least $10$ programmers and $5$ analysts should be used while the company only has $6$ terminals available. In this situation, what are the decision variables to formalize the Linear Programming (LP) model that allows planning the company's activity?
answer1: $x_{i}$ is the number of developed project $i$ ($i=1$, for project $A$ and $i=2$, for project $B$)
answer2: $x_{2}$ is the number of developed projects $B$
answer3: $x_{1}$ is the number of developed projects $A$
answer4: $x$ is the number of developed projects $A$ and $B$

question:
Ralph Edmund loves steaks and potatoes. Therefore, he has decided to go on a steady diet of only these two foods (plus some liquids and vitamin supplements) for all his meals. Ralph realizes that this isn't the healthiest diet, so he wants to make sure that he eats the right quantities of the two foods to satisfy some key nutritional requirements. He has obtained the following nutritional and cost information:

\[
\begin{array}{|l|c|c|c|}
\hline
%& \multicolumn{2}{c|}{Grams of ingredient per serving} &\\
\text{Ingredient} & \text{Steak (gr. per serving)} & \text{Potatoes (gr. per serving)} & \text{Daily Requirements (gr.)} \\
\hline
\text{Carbohydrates} & 5 & 15 & \geq 50 \\
\text{Protein} & 20 & 5 & \geq 40 \\
\text{Fat} & 15 & 2 & \leq 60 \\
\hline
\text{Cost per serving} & 4 & 2 &  \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]
	
Use a computer (Solver Add-in in Excel) to solve this model by the simplex method to allow planning the Ralph's diet, considering that $x_{i}$ is the number of daily servings of food $i$ ($i=1$, for steak and $i=2$, for potatoes).

answer4:

answer1: The sample range is at least $30 001$ but at most $90 000$.
answer3: The sample range is at least $30 000$ but  at most $90 000$.

\[f:\mathbb{R}^{3}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}, f(x_{1},x_{2},x_{3})=x_{1}x_{2}x_{3} \]under the constraint 
\[x_{1}x_{2}+x_{1}x_{3}+x_{2}x_{3}-8=0.\]
answer1:
$f\left(  -\frac{2\sqrt{6}}{3},-\frac{2\sqrt{6}}{3},-\frac{2\sqrt{6}}{3}\right)$ is the minimum.

 $f\left(  \frac{2\sqrt{6}}{3},\frac{2\sqrt{6}}{3},\frac{2\sqrt{6}}{3}\right)  \ $ is the minimum.
answer3: The fuction has no extremum points.
answer4:
$f(0,0,0)$ is the minimum.
$f(1,1,1)$ is the maximum.
